As everything was then
going smoothly, I drove up to the
Peninsula Hotel in the most complete blackout you could imagine.
It was a very difficult, job in itself.
The purpose of my trip was
to see as many Government officials and important Chinese that I
could who might be able to leave quickly.
I saw Mr.
Mr. Hsi Teh Mou,
of the Central Bank, and told them we would evacu-
ate them and their families that night if they could go.
Mr. Loy
Chang said he was unable to leave that night and Mr. Mou was uncer-
Mr. Mou took me up to Mr. Fox's room; Mr. Fox is head of
the Stabilization Board.
I told Mr. Fox that we would be able to
take out eight people that night, provided they could be at the Air-
port, bringing 10 kilograms of baggage each.
Hr. K. P. Chen was
there also with Mr. Fox and I told him wa could
take him and his
wife, Included in this eight.

of his staff, particularly Mr. Frese,
a baby, and sir. Taylor, also of the Stabilization Board.

I then phoned Mr. Fox to send his party to the Airport

About three quarters of an hour later his
party
